name: The Self
title: Atum - The Self-Created God | Egyptian Mythology
epithets: The Complete One, First God, Setting Sun
description:
The Self stands as one of the most ancient and mysterious figures in Egyptian mythology. 

According to Egyptian sacred texts, The Self's origins arise from the primordial waters of Nun, manifesting divine order (Ma'at) from chaos The worship of The Self became central to Egyptian religious practice, with devotees seeking their favor through temple offerings, festival processions, and elaborate funerary rites. 

Sacred symbols associated with The Self include egyptian symbolism. These emblems appear throughout Egyptian art and literature, serving as powerful reminders of The Self's divine presence and authority. The mythology surrounding The Self reveals deep insights into Egyptian worldview, particularly concerning unknown and humanity's relationship with the divine. 

The legacy of The Self extends far beyond ancient Egyptian civilization. The Self captivates the modern imagination through museum exhibitions, esoteric traditions, and popular media. The deity's iconography remains instantly recognizable worldwide Scholars continue to study The Self's mythology for its profound insights into Egyptian culture, religion, and philosophy.

listDisplay.expandedContent: Atumis the self-created primordial deity who emerged from the waters of Nun at creation. He represents completion and the setting sun. Often merged withRaasAtum-Ra, he masturbated or spat to create Shu (air) and Tefnut (moisture), beginning theEnnead. He is both the first and last god, present at creation and at the end of time.

epithets: The Complete One, First God, Setting Sun

sections.title: Description
sections.content: Atumis the self-created primordial deity who emerged from the waters of Nun at creation. He represents completion and the setting sun. Often merged withRaasAtum-Ra, he masturbated or spat to create Shu (air) and Tefnut (moisture), beginning theEnnead. He is both the first and last god, present at creation and at the end of time.

epithets: The Complete One, First God, Setting Sun

summary: Atumis the self-created primordial deity who emerged from the waters of Nun at creation.  He represents completion and the setting sun.
cultural_significance: A significant deity in egyptian mythology, widely worshipped and culturally influential.

topic_panels.title: Origins & Mythology
topic_panels.content:
### Sacred Origins

The Self's mythology primordial waters (Nun), creator gods, cosmogonies. The deity's role in Egyptian cosmology reflects fundamental aspects of how ancient peoples understood divine power and cosmic order.

### Creation Accounts

Primary sources describe The Self's emergence and divine nature through various sacred narratives. These origin stories served both religious and cultural functions, establishing divine authority and cosmic principles.

**Time Period:** c. 3000 BCE - 400 CE

topic_panels.title: Worship & Practice
topic_panels.content:
### Religious Practice

Worship of The Self involved temple rituals, festivals, funerary practices. These practices created sacred bonds between devotees and the divine realm.

### Sacred Sites

Throughout Ancient Egypt, Nile Valley, temples and shrines dedicated to The Self served as focal points for religious activity. Priests and priestesses maintained sacred rituals that ensured divine favor and cosmic balance.

### Festivals & Ceremonies

Special festivals celebrated The Self's divine attributes and mythological deeds, bringing communities together in shared religious expression.

topic_panels.title: Symbols & Iconography
topic_panels.content:
### Sacred Symbols

Key symbols associated with The Self:

- **egyptian symbolism**: Represents divine power and sacred authority

### Divine Attributes

The iconography reveals how ancient peoples visualized divine power and cosmic forces.

### Artistic Representations

Ancient artworks depict The Self with distinctive attributes that communicate divine identity and authority to worshippers.

topic_panels.title: Modern Influence
topic_panels.content:
### Cultural Legacy

Hermeticism, Western esotericism, popular culture. The mythology of The Self continues to resonate in contemporary culture, literature, and spiritual practices.

### Academic Study

Modern scholars analyze The Self's mythology through multiple lenses‚Äîreligious studies, anthropology, archaeology, and comparative mythology‚Äîrevealing insights into ancient worldviews.

### Popular Culture

The Self appears in modern media, from fantasy novels to video games, demonstrating the enduring power of ancient mythology to capture human imagination and address timeless questions.
